clinical_study.official_title: Are Steroids Efficacious in Hospitalized Patients With Bronchiolitis Who Show an Objective Clinical Improvement After Albuterol ("Albuterol Responders")?

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of the study is to determine whether corticosteroids are beneficial to children with bronchiolitis whose breathing gets better after being given a breathing treatment with albuterol.

clinical_study.why_stopped: We were unable to enroll a sufficient number of patients due to manpower.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: respiratory rate and respiratory distress score
length of hospitalization (actual and until meets "ready for discharge" criteria)
primary_outcome.time_frame: variable, likely no more than 2 weeks

secondary_outcome.measure: need for increased respiratory support (intubation, CPAP, BiPAP)
amount of oxygen used during hospitalization
number of doses of bronchodilators used during hospitalization
secondary_outcome.time_frame: variable, likely no more than 2 weeks
variable, likely no more than 3 weeks

secondary_outcome.measure: need for unanticipated medical care after discharge
secondary_outcome.time_frame: variable, likely no more than 3 weeks
variable, likely no more than 2 weeks

intervention.description: either prednisolone 2mg/kg PO once daily or methylprednisolone 1.6mg/kg IV once daily (if IV access is present) for length of hospitalization, for a maximum of seven days

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- diagnosis of bronchiolitis
- Respiratory Distress Assessment Index score of 4 or more
Exclusion Criteria:
- prior prescription of bronchodilators or inhaled corticosteroids
- birth at <36 weeks gestation
- chronic cardiac disease
- chronic pulmonary disease (including asthma)
- immunodeficiency
- non-topical steroid use in the prior week
- parents that don't understand English
- baseline systolic blood pressure >118 mmHg
- home oxygen use
- evidence of systemic fungal or varicella infection
- bronchodilator use in the prior week
- allergy to albuterol or corticosteroids
